title: African Burial Ground National Monument: Park Home
body: A Sacred Space in Manhattan  From about the 1690s until 1794, both free and enslaved Africans were buried in a 6.6-acre burial ground in Lower Manhattan, outside the boundaries of the settlement of New Amsterdam, later known as New York. Lost to history due to landfill and development, the grounds were rediscovered in 1991 as a consequence of the planned construction of a Federal office building.              Celebrate Independence Day   We will be open for Independence Day, join us for special programming!            Every Kid in a Park   The Every Kid in a Park initiative invites every 4th grade student to visit a national park during the 2015-2016 school year for free.        Celebrating 100 Years of Service   On Aug. 25, 2016, the National Park Service turns 100! The Centennial will begin a second century of stewardship of America's national parks        Book a tour at African Burial Ground!   Groups of all ages enjoy our ranger-led tours.
